poem_title: A Pindarick, to the Athenian Society.

lines.line_text: I'VE toucht  each muse I have invok't,

Perhaps, the  is provok't.
I grasp a Subject fit for none but him,
Or  sweeter lays;

stanzas.stanza_text:
I'VE toucht  each muse I have invok't,
Yet still the mighty theam,
Copes my unequal praise;
Perhaps, the  is provok't.
I grasp a Subject fit for none but him,
Or  sweeter lays;
A name I ne're could yet rehearse,
But straight my thoughts

lines.line_text: And now methinks I rise;
But still the  baulks my slight,
And still my  despairs to do great  right;
Yet takes the  which I bring,
The early products of a Female muse;
Untill  into my breast shall
When I with more Command, and  shall sing;
But how shall I describe the matchless men?
I'm lost in the  agen.
When the  as ignorant as accurst,
Arriv'd in vice and error to the worst,
And like  banisht from the stage,
Virtue and Truth were ready
Their numerous foes,
Scarce one of eithers Champions ventur'd to oppose;
Scarce one  durst openly engage,
To do them right.
Till prompted with a generous rage;
You cop't with all th' abuses of the age;
Unmaskt and  its abhorred crimes,
Nor fear'd to  the darling vices of the times.

stanzas.stanza_text:
When the  as ignorant as accurst,
Arriv'd in vice and error to the worst,
And like  banisht from the stage,
Virtue and Truth were ready
Their numerous foes,
Scarce one of eithers Champions ventur'd to oppose;
Scarce one  durst openly engage,
To do them right.
Till prompted with a generous rage;
You cop't with all th' abuses of the age;
Unmaskt and  its abhorred crimes,
Nor fear'd to  the darling vices of the times.

lines.line_text: Successfully go on,
T' inform and bless mankind as you've begun,
Till like your selves they see;
The frantick world's imagin'd Joys to be,
Unmanly, sensual and effeminate,
Till they with such exalted thoughts possest;
As you've inspir'd into my
Are  like me, from the impending fate.

lines.line_text: For ah!  I blush to say't,
I with the vulgar world thought
Tho fine my breeding, and my Notions high;
Tho train'd in the  tracts of strictest piety,
I' like my  soon grew vain,
And laid my slighted innocence a side;
Yet oft my nobler thoughts I have bely'd,
And to be ill was

lines.line_text: Oh, could my verse;
With  to after times rehearse,
Your  It should as bright and Deathless be;
As that immortal flame you've rais'd in me.
A flame which time:
And Death it self, wants power to controul,
